issue.title: Case sensitive regexp
issue.body: It would be very useful to make the filters case-insensitive by configuration.

comment.body: Confirming that prepending `(?i)` solves my issue as well.

issue.title: [FR]: Recidive with journald
issue.body:
<!--
  - Before requesting, please make sure to search the open and closed issues for any requests in the past.
  - Sometimes failregex have been already requested before but are not implemented yet due to various reasons.
  - If there are no hits for your concerns, please proceed otherwise add a comment to the related issue (also if it is closed).
  - If you want to request a new feature, please use "Feature request" instead.
  - If you have rather some question, please open or join to some discussion.
-->

### Environment:

<!--
  Fill out and check (`[x]`) the boxes which apply.
-->

- Fail2Ban version <!-- including any possible distribution suffixes --> : 1.0.2
- OS, including release name/version : Debian 11

#### Service, project or product which log or journal should be monitored

- Name of filter or jail in Fail2Ban (if already exists) : recidive
- Service, project or product name, including release name/version : recidive
- Repository or URL (if known) : 
- Service type : 
- Ports and protocols the service is listening : 

#### Log or journal information
<!-- Systemd journal -->

- Journal identifier or unit name : fail2ban

#### Any additional information

It seems that recidive does not match journald entries for bans.  That is, when fail2ban is itself logging to journald, recidive does not seem to match any entries.

### Relevant lines from monitored log files:

#### failures in sense of fail2ban filter (fail2ban must match):
<!-- put your log excerpt between next 2 lines -->
```
Oct 09 23:23:50 test.com fail2ban[52973]: [sshd] Ban 218.92.0.118
```

#### legitimate messages (fail2ban should not consider as failures):
<!-- put your log excerpt between next 2 lines -->
```
```

comment.body:
Thanks!
Yes, I had just seen the bantime.increment feature and it's probably better for my use case :)

issue.title: [FR]: Recidive with journald
issue.body:
<!--
  - Before requesting, please make sure to search the open and closed issues for any requests in the past.
  - Sometimes failregex have been already requested before but are not implemented yet due to various reasons.
  - If there are no hits for your concerns, please proceed otherwise add a comment to the related issue (also if it is closed).
  - If you want to request a new feature, please use "Feature request" instead.
  - If you have rather some question, please open or join to some discussion.
-->

### Environment:

<!--
  Fill out and check (`[x]`) the boxes which apply.
-->

- Fail2Ban version <!-- including any possible distribution suffixes --> : 1.0.2
- OS, including release name/version : Debian 11

#### Service, project or product which log or journal should be monitored

- Name of filter or jail in Fail2Ban (if already exists) : recidive
- Service, project or product name, including release name/version : recidive
- Repository or URL (if known) : 
- Service type : 
- Ports and protocols the service is listening : 

#### Log or journal information
<!-- Systemd journal -->

- Journal identifier or unit name : fail2ban

#### Any additional information

It seems that recidive does not match journald entries for bans.  That is, when fail2ban is itself logging to journald, recidive does not seem to match any entries.

### Relevant lines from monitored log files:

#### failures in sense of fail2ban filter (fail2ban must match):
<!-- put your log excerpt between next 2 lines -->
```
Oct 09 23:23:50 test.com fail2ban[52973]: [sshd] Ban 218.92.0.118
```

#### legitimate messages (fail2ban should not consider as failures):
<!-- put your log excerpt between next 2 lines -->
```
```

comment.body:
Recidive jail is a rudiment and retained as it is for backwards-compatibility only.
Better is to use `bantime.increment` feature instead.

However it is planned to create new backend `recidive`, which doesn't monitor any file/journal anymore, but will be directly notified about bans (= single attempt) from observer module.

So long as this is not implemented yet, you can use this jail config for that:
```ini
[recidive]
filter =
backend = systemd
failregex = ^\s*\S+ fail2ban\[\d+\]: \[[^\]]+\] Ban <ADDR>
journalmatch = _SYSTEMD_UNIT=fail2ban.service + _COMM=fail2ban
enabled = true
```

issue.title: [RFE]: Support for Cloudflare bearer authorization
issue.body:
#### Feature request type
Fail2ban is currently using legacy authorization for Cloudflare. Can we support Cloudflare current, non-legacy authorization for the action for: https://github.com/fail2ban/fail2ban/blob/master/config/action.d/cloudflare.conf

#### Description
Existing Fail2Ban Cloudflare auth: `-H 'X-Auth-Email: <cfuser>' -H 'X-Auth-Key: <cftoken>'`

Cloudflare current, non-legacy authorization is: `-H 'Authorization: Bearer <API_TOKEN>'`

https://developers.cloudflare.com/fundamentals/api/get-started/create-token/

To preserve existing functionality, does it make sense to:

1. Do a new file name i.e. cloudflare-bearer.conf (or similar) AND let me know the file name you'd like
OR
2. Add to /action.d/cloudflare.conf as COMMENTED code:

LINE: 68
```
_cf_api_prms = -H 'X-Auth-Email: <cfuser>' -H 'X-Auth-Key: <cftoken>' -H 'Content-Type: application/json'
# _cf_api_prms = -H 'Authorization: Bearer <cfbearer>' -H 'Content-Type: application/json'
```

LINE: 81
```
cftoken =

cfuser =

# cfbearer = 
```

AND add explanation with this link at the top: https://developers.cloudflare.com/fundamentals/api/get-started/create-token/

Given the ease of this change and the code already posted in this issue, I'd imagine someone could easily slot it into their existing workflow. If not, I'm happy to do a pull request. Let me know. Thanks!

comment.body: Thanks for pointing that out. I have 0.11.2-6 installed via hestia-cp. They haven't added 1.0.2-2 yet so that file was missing for me. I should have checked the versions first and looked that the current release before posting. Sorry to waste your time. Thanks!

pull_request.title: Ensure FROM email field is populated correctly when using Postfix
pull_request.body: I am using Fail2Ban v0.8.13. In this version, I had to modify also "config/jail.conf" "action_*" lines used for emailing to include ", sender=%(sender)s", but this version already have that. Though, it no more includes "sendername" in those lines, but the sendmail.conf still use "sendername", so I presume it would work as my current configuration.
